headline: Tesla Shifts From Premium EVs To Robotaxis As Autopilot Scrutiny Grows
summary: Tesla is discontinuing its long-running Model S and Model X vehicles and reallocating factory capacity toward robotaxis and the Optimus humanoid robot program. The company is preparing new autonomous-focused vehicles, including the Cybercab, as part of its robotaxi ambitions. Tesla has stopped using the Autopilot label in California marketing following regulatory scrutiny tied to driver assistance claims. A jury recently issued a $243 million verdict related to Autopilot, adding legal...

headline: Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure Market Company Analysis Report 2025 Featuring ABB, ChargePoint,, Blink Charging, Eaton, and Tesla
summary: The global electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure market is projected to experience significant growth, increasing from a valuation of US$ 40.26 billion in 2025 to approximately US$ 258.53 billion by 2033, at a CAGR of 26.17%. This surge is driven by the widespread adoption of EVs, favorable government policies, and rising investments in transport infrastructure. Charging infrastructure, including Level 1, Level 2, and DC fast charging, is expanding through public and private involvement.

Charging infrastructure, including Level 1, Level 2, and DC fast charging, is expanding through public and private involvement.

headline: Waymo's robotaxis now being dispatched in 10 major U.S. markets with expansion in Texas and Florida
summary: Waymo will begin dispatching its robotaxis in four more cities in Texas and Florida, expanding the territory covered by its fleet of self-driving cars to 10 major U.S. metropolitan markets.  The move into Dallas, Houston, San Antonio and Orlando, Florida, announced Tuesday, widens Waymo's early lead in autonomous driving while rival services from Tesla and the Amazon-owned Zoox are still testing their vehicles in only a few U.S. cities.  In contrast, Waymo's robotaxis already provide more than 400,000 weekly trips in the six metropolitan areas where they have been transporting passengers: Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Miami, Atlanta, and Austin, Texas.

content.title: Waymo's robotaxis now being dispatched in 10 major U.S. markets with expansion in Texas and Florida
content.summary: Waymo will begin dispatching its robotaxis in four more cities in Texas and Florida, expanding the territory covered by its fleet of self-driving cars to 10 major U.S. metropolitan markets.  The move into Dallas, Houston, San Antonio and Orlando, Florida, announced Tuesday, widens Waymo's early lead in autonomous driving while rival services from Tesla and the Amazon-owned Zoox are still testing their vehicles in only a few U.S. cities.  In contrast, Waymo's robotaxis already provide more than 400,000 weekly trips in the six metropolitan areas where they have been transporting passengers: Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Miami, Atlanta, and Austin, Texas.

headline: The EU Warms To Chinese EVs. BYD Registrations In Europe Grow 165%.
summary: BYD's designs to expand outside of China continue apace.  January new car registration figures suggest the car company is off to an outstanding start this year in Europe.  BYD new car registrations rose 165% in January compared to last year, according to data released Tuesday by the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA).

headline: Tesla must face lawsuit alleging anti-American bias in hiring, US judge rules
summary: judge has refused to dismiss a lawsuit accusing Tesla of discriminating against American citizens in hiring so it can pay less ‌to foreign workers, but said he was skeptical that the software engineer who sued ‌would prevail. District Judge Vince Chhabria in San Francisco said in a brief order late Monday that Scott Taub, who filed ​the proposed class action in September, had offered up "just enough facts" about Tesla's hiring practices for the case to move forward.

content.title: Tesla must face lawsuit alleging anti-American bias in hiring, US judge rules
content.summary: judge has refused to dismiss a lawsuit accusing Tesla of discriminating against American citizens in hiring so it can pay less ‌to foreign workers, but said he was skeptical that the software engineer who sued ‌would prevail. District Judge Vince Chhabria in San Francisco said in a brief order late Monday that Scott Taub, who filed ​the proposed class action in September, had offered up "just enough facts" about Tesla's hiring practices for the case to move forward.
